ranked_diseases.explanation: Patient presents with exact phenotypic match to reference cases: nystagmus, very low visual acuity, eye poking, and hypermetropia. All reference cases with this phenotype constellation were diagnosed with LCA6.
Classic LCA presentation with severe visual impairment from infancy, nystagmus, and eye poking (oculodigital sign). LCA1 is caused by GUCY2D mutations and presents similarly to LCA6.
RPE65-related LCA presenting with severe early-onset retinal dystrophy, nystagmus, and characteristic eye poking behavior. Hypermetropia is common in LCA2.
CEP290-related LCA is the most common form, presenting with severe visual impairment, nystagmus, and oculodigital sign. Matches core phenotype but less specific than LCA6 given reference cases.
CNGA3-related achromatopsia presents with nystagmus, severely reduced visual acuity, and hypermetropia. However, typically has better visual function than LCA and lacks eye poking.
Can present with nystagmus, reduced visual acuity, and hypermetropia. However, eye poking is not typical, and usually has characteristic hypopigmentation features not mentioned.
